awd_titl_txt: NEESR: Inertial Force-Limiting Floor Anchorage Systems for Seismic Resistant Building Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research project is to advance knowledge toward the development of innovative floor anchorage systems that reduce inertial forces during earthquakes and maintain a centered floor afterward. This new knowledge will be generated through a combination of analytical and experimental research, including nonlinear transient dynamic analysis, and using the equipment and tools available at two George E. Brown, Jr. Network for Earthquake Engineering Simulation (NEES) facilities: the large scale structural and hybrid testing laboratory at Lehigh University and shake table testing at the University of California, San Diego (UCSD). The project will first explore new knowledge of the dynamic behavior of building structures with inertial force-limiting floor anchorage systems. With this knowledge, the project will determine the appropriate design parameters for this system to produce optimal seismic performance for a variety of building geometries and properties. The ultimate goal of the research will be to produce a feasible prototype design for one or more candidate structures that can be used in dissemination of the concept to the practice. Data from the project will be archived and made available to the public through the NEES Project Warehouse/data repository, available at http://www.nees.org.  This project is a collaborative effort among researchers from the University of Arizona, Lehigh University, UCSD, and Universita di Roma, La Sapienza, and practitioners from two seismic design firms.

The concept has the potential for producing more economical and safer seismic designs with application to a wide array of construction types and building systems. The benefits of such a system include: (1) reduced seismic forces; (2) reduced structural lateral drift; (3) reduced structural damage; (4) reduced nonstructural and contents damage; and (5) a higher factor of safety against collapse. If successful, this research can transform the manner in which structures are designed to resist earthquakes by modifying the response to strong ground motion and thereby significantly impacting the cost-effectiveness of the U.S. construction industry. Effective transfer of research results into practice will be facilitated through team members who are practicing engineers at two seismic design firms. International collaboration will facilitate exchange with the broader earthquake engineering community. An outreach program with the K-12 community  in Tucson, Arizona, will expose students in the next generation to the importance of earthquake hazard mitigation. This award is part of the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program (NEHRP).

por.por_cntn:
The Project "NEESR: Inertial Force-Limiting Floor Anchorage Systems for Seismic Resistant Building Structures" is a multi-university research project led by the University of Arizona, and involving researchers at Lehigh University and University of California-San Diego. The project conceived, developed, prototyped and successfully demonstrated a new technique for connecting the floors to the primary walls or braced frames in multi-story building structures that reduces the seismic demands during an earthquake. The concept, term IFAS (Inertial Force-Limiting Floor Anchorage System) has application to a wide variety of building structures (for instance, office towers, apartment buildings, hospitals, data centers, etc.), and is applicable to both steel and concrete construction.

This IFAS objective is realized by providing a deformable connection between the floor and the primary vertical elements (walls, etc.). The deformable connection is initially very stiff and thus the structure will respond as a traditional building during daily service wind loading. However, in an earthquake, the connection will reach its "slip load" and the floors will begin to "slide" relative to the walls. This sliding limits the seismic forces that develop in a building during an earthquake, and the deformable connection also has characteristics such that it dissipates ("dampens") the (unwanted) energy introduced into the building by the earthquake. To make the connection system practical, the relative movement (sliding) of the floors relative to the walls is limited to 4-6", after which the floor hits a rubber bumper that limits its relative motion, keeping the building stable, and making the required architectural details (for cladding, partitions, mechanicals etc.) reasonable.

The project developed a prototype system, termed the  IFAS prototype, composed of friction dampers (steel plates with brass shims that are bolted together with long slotted holes to allow sliding under friction) or other dampers, rubber bearings to brace the walls against the floor but still allow sliding motion, and the aforementioned rubber bumpers.

The optimum design of the IFAS prototype was determined through extensive computer simulation of buildings with trial versions of the system. The system design parameters and configuration were determined jointly by the research team and seismic design consultants associated with the project. International collaborators (from Universita di Roma and Nazarbayev University) studied the optimum layout of these devices in a building.

The IFAS prototype system was first designed and tested at full-scale at the NEES@Lehigh Structural Laboratory. Then a scaled version of the prototype system was installed in a half-scale 4-story building structure on the shake table platform at NEES@UCSD. The building specimen was specially designed to allow repeated "shake" tests of the structure, and had inserts embedded in the wall to allow the structure to be converted from an "IFAS" structure to a "traditional" building structure with rigidly-attached floors, by locking down the floors after the first set of tests. This approach allowed the IFAS structure to be directly compared to a traditional structure.

In the shake tests, the IFAS structure exhibited significantly lower building interstory drifts (the measure of how far one level of a building is "tipping over"), significantly lower "twisting" response (a particularly destructive mode of response to an earthquake), and lower accelerations for most of the earthquakes simulated on the table.
